summary: This is an academic article from the Journal of Interpersonal Violence discussing the historical origins and usage of the terms 'grooming' and 'seduction' in the context of child sexual abuse. The author, Park Dietz, analyzes the evolution of these terms in professional literature and cautions against misuse, particularly in litigation. The article references key figures in the field like Ken Lanning and historical cases like McMartin and Father Gilbert Caudle.

persons.name: Park Dietz
persons.context: Author of the academic article analyzing the terms 'grooming' and 'seduction' in child sexual abuse literature. He is a forensic psychiatrist and president of Park Dietz & Associates.

persons.name: Ken Lanning
persons.context: Cited as a key figure who disseminated the concept of non-forceful acquaintance molestation and the use of the term 'grooming' to law enforcement and mental health professionals.

persons.name: Ann Burgess
persons.context: Mentioned as one of the thought leaders who helped spread the concept of grooming through teaching and training in the 1980s and 1990s.

persons.name: John Conte
persons.context: Author of the 1984 article identified as the first publication to use the term 'grooming' in the context of child sexual abuse techniques.

persons.name: A. Nicholas Groth
persons.context: Co-author of 'Men Who Rape' (1979), which described the grooming process but did not use the term.

persons.name: H. Jean Birnbaum
persons.context: Co-author of 'Men Who Rape' (1979) with A. Nicholas Groth.

persons.name: Sigmund Freud
persons.context: Referenced regarding his 'seduction hypothesis' and the historical, vague use of the term 'seduction' in early psychoanalytic literature.

persons.name: Lauretta Bender
persons.context: Cited in historical examples (1937, 1952) that used the archaic concept of the 'child as seducer'.

persons.name: Abraham Blau
persons.context: Co-author with Lauretta Bender on a 1937 article referencing the 'child as seducer' concept.

persons.name: Roland Summit
persons.context: Cited for his 1983 work challenging the archaic view that children are often seductive or vindictive in abuse accusations.

connections.description: Co-authored a 2014 article on acquaintance molestation and youth-serving organizations. Dietz's article supports and expands upon Lanning's work.
Both are described as thought leaders who spread the concept of grooming through teaching and training in the same era.
Co-authors of the 1979 book 'Men Who Rape', which described the grooming process.
Co-authors of a 1937 article that used the archaic concept of the 'child as seducer'.

events.title: First Academic Use of 'Grooming'
events.description: John Conte's 1984 article is identified as the first publication in professional literature to use the term 'grooming' to describe techniques for gaining sexual access to children.

events.title: McMartin and Father Gilbert Caudle Cases
events.description: Media reports about the McMartin Preschool case and the case of Father Gilbert Caudle first broke, bringing the possibility of non-forceful acquaintance molestation into public consciousness.

events.title: Publication of 'Men Who Rape'
events.description: Groth and Birnbaum publish 'Men Who Rape', which describes the grooming process but does not use the term itself.

keyFacts: The term 'grooming' was first introduced in the peer-reviewed professional literature on child sexual abuse in a 1984 article by John Conte.

The recognition that many child sexual abuse cases involve acquaintances using non-forceful techniques (grooming/seduction) burst into public consciousness in the mid-1980s, partly due to media coverage of the McMartin and Father Gilbert Caudle cases.

The article warns against two archaic and problematic uses of the term 'seduction': as a vague euphemism for any child-adult sexual contact, and as a concept blaming the child as the 'seducer' of the adult.
The author argues against abandoning the term 'grooming' in favor of 'seduction' due to this historical baggage and suggests using the terms in tandem with clear explanation.
The article notes the misuse of the term 'grooming' in civil litigation, where it is sometimes incorrectly applied to common, desirable behaviors to imply negligence by organizations.
